intro: Diplopappus candidus, commonly known as the white burrweed, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its erect, herbaceous growth habit and produces small, white to pale yellow flowers. The plant's most distinctive feature is its unique seed dispersal mechanism, involving a two-part pappus that aids in wind dispersal. It thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and coastal areas. Due to its adaptability, it is considered a resilient species in its native environment.
